document.text: The Town of Appomattox has made a change in the set-up for trying town court cases. The Town has appointed J. W. Cawthorn, re tired town manager, as its judge to try town cases and preside over the town court. A former mayor and town manager until his retirement two years ago, Mr. Cawthorn is well versed in town law and procedure. He will be paid a monthly compen sation and the compensation will not be based on fees.

document.text: sister Southern States, which had already seceded. The call went out for volunteers to defend the firesides of the Old Do minion. Appomattox County responded nobly. A Cavalry Company was formed under the command of Capt. Joel W. Flood, becoming Co. H of the 2nd Va. Cavalry. A Company of Heavy Artillery was formed under Capt. James Robertson. A Company of Infantry under Capt. Thos. P. Mat thews, and another Company was formed under Capt. Wm. H. Abbitt, and quite a number of Appomattox citizens living near the rim of the county joined companies from adjoining coun ties. With hearts aflame and bodies dedicated to the Cause they held dear, they went to the front and shared the destiny of the heroes in Gray. Weakened by casualties, new calls came for volunteers, and long after the war, there was a scarcity of able bodied men in the County. Then came April 9, 1865, and the hand of destiny wrote finis across the scroll of four mighty years of struggle Destiny selected Appomattox for one of the major events oi history. Today there is hardly a town- or village in America, that has not heard of Appomattox. Thus ended in this Coun ty, one of the greatest Civil Wars ever chronicled in the files of Time, and at Appomattox began a new page in the history of America. Military rule was established shortly after April 9, 1865. Al county officers were replaced by military appointees. These were men who were selected upon the recommendation of the incumbents, and were willing to take the Iron Clad Oath. In the fall of 1866, an election was held under the Under wood Constitution, which put into effect the 13th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and a new slate of officers were named. Geo. T. Peers became Clerk Wm. T. Johnson Sheriff W. J. Collins, Commissioner of the Revenue the Office of County Treasurer was created Supervisors were provided for, and the ounty Government, practically as we have it now was estab lished. The ravages of four years of war were apparent, and Ap pomattox along with her sister counties, began to repair the wounds. The following years called forth the character and ability of her people, and the present institutions of our Coun- -y are but a tribute to their untiring labor and foresight. From 1870 to the present has been a period of rebuilding and achievement. From its creation the County has been served until now by the following Officers CIRCUIT JUDGESJudges G. A. Wingfield, J. D. Hors- rv, Sam Coleman, George J. Hundley, Robt. F. Hutcheson and Joel W. Flood. COUNTY JUDGESLewis Daniel Isbell, Henry T. Par-  rish and David A. Christian. TRIAL JUSTICEST. R. Horseley and L. F. Ferguson. COUNTY CLERKSJohn T. Bocock, Henry F. Bocock, Geo. T. Peers, Geo. W. Abbitt, John Rolfe Horsley and Claude W. Smith. , COMMONWEALTHS ATTORNEYSThos. S. Bocock, L. D. Isbell, Crawford Jones, Edward Woodson, T. J. Thornhill, David A. Christian, W. C. Franklin, H. D. Flood, Samuel L. Ferguson, Joel W. Flood and W. M. Abbitt. SHERIFFSJoel Watkins, Geo. T. document.text: Sheriff McKinney, E. R. A b- bitt and Reuben B ryant had  been busy for several days ar-1 ranging a Farm ers Union picnic for Friday, A ugust 23rd, I at this place. I Early Friday morning the teams with trunks and baskets I began to arrive and by ton oclock about the time of the parade at least 1500 people were I thronging the streets. The town was turned over to the farm ers and they enjoyed the day in every way.  . The Farm ville Silver Band furnished splendid music for the occasion and our boys girls joined in the parade and the festivities of the occasion. President of the County Union, J. W . Cawthorn, Jr., introduced A. B. Thornhill, who spoke on the objects of the Union and welcomed the far mers, their wives and daugh ters and the visitors to the ele g an t dinner w hich was spread on the Court Green, Mr. F. A. LaBaume, Indus trial A gent of the N.  W . Ry., who had been invited to ad dress the farm ers, was intro duced by Mr. Thornhill, and made a very practical speech, interspersed by many am using jokes. He paid Appomattox a high com plim ent on her splen did enterprise, progress and commended especially the I great Work being done by Prof. Crawley in our fine Agricul tural College. He told the farm ers how to beautify their  homes and keep the boys on the farm. Mr. LaBaume is a good speaker and the large audience enjoyed his rem arks very much and no doubt w ill gather some inspiration there from fpr greater effort tow ards real progress. . President Ganaway, pf Cum berland, w ae present and made an address w hich was much enjoyed.  Btate Secretary D. M. Blank- inship, of Campbell County, was also present and m ade a good business talk to the far mers. The day was strictly a far m ers day and they are to be congratulated on the big suc cess of their picnic, and now we w ant to move that they m ake thefourth Friday in Au gust every year the annual picnic day of the Farm ers Union at Appomattox. The interest and attendance shows th at the Union is here to stay and th at the substantial saving which is being made to the farm ers in their respective Unions is worth the considera tion of those who are not mem bers. There were several m atch games of base ball played, and the entire day was given over to one of pleasure and social intercourse. Come again farm ers, and long live the Union.

document.text: Platform ot Principles Adopt ed. Party Organization. Much Enthusiasm. Large Attend ance. Pursuant to a call of Dr. D. M. Robertson, Chairman, of the Citizens Party a large and enthusiastic meeting of citi zens assembled in mass meet ing at the Courthouse here Fri day and adopted a platform of principles and practically put a full tioket in the field for all County and District1 officers in opposition to the nominees of the Democratio party. Every seat in the Courthouse was oc cupied and m an were stand ing in the aisles. The crowd was estimated at 200.  Many of these, however, were specta tors, and not in sympathy with the movement. Dr. L. M. Robertson, Chair man, appointedthe following Committee on Resolutions J. W. Cawthorn Jr., R. S. Jen kins, David Alvis, E. F. Col- lips, S. P. Coleman and J. T. jGotas. While the committee was out J. P. L. Fleshman addressed the meeting. Mr. Fleshman has been a Republican for many years his remarks were direct ed against the office-holders of Appqmattox County, particu larly for raising the assessed values and the rate of taxation he referred to a notice posted by the Superintendent of Schools, 1800 for schools and 1700 for incidentals. He wanted the receipts and dis bursements published of the school fund, also the road fund and the Supervisors proceed ings. He wants Appomattox to sell her poor houses and pay her debts, two poor houses and three paupers is too expensive, he deolared. He opposed a bond issue, saying it would make slaves of the people. The Committee on Resolu tions then made its report and the chair requested J.- W. Caw- thon, the Chairman, to ex- lain to the meeting the reso- utions they were unanimously adopted. We, the citizens of Appomat tox County in mass-meeting assembled at the Courthouse of said county on this the 20th day of August, 1915 desirous of promoting our own welfare and that of every other - citizen of our county do make the fol lowing declaration of princi ples and for the support of this declaration we mutually pledge to each other our influence and our votes. We demand a more economi cal administration of our State and county affairs, and that all taxes and licenses be eq a- ized as nearly as possible and that the poll tax be made col lectible as other taxes and abolished as a prequisite to voting. We demand the repeal of the aw appointing the  board of review to do over the work al ready performed by the -con? missioners of the revenue, as this is a useless waste of money and very objectionable to the people. We believe that it is detri mental to the best interests of the people for any county offi cial to bold office for a period of more than two terms, as ex perience has proved that many of them become seif-perpetuat ing political bosses, thus caus ing a detriment to the public welfare. We demand that the expen sive, antiquated system of deeds and mortgages be discon tinned and a modern system be adopted, such as the Torrens system, whioh would be a sav ing to the people of Virginia of a half million to one million dollars a year. We demand that the State publish and distribute its school books at cost, which would mean a large annual saving to our people. We demand that our old sol diers be better provided for in thoir declining years and th at

document.text: On the morning of July 23, our ,aople were shocked beyond power t expression as the sad news spread iirough our little town that Tad ears was la d . What! Tad lears dead? Why he waited on me n the store only yesterday and eemed to be perfectly well and many similiar expressions were heard. Yes Tad is dead, we will see hiln no more in the flesh, but let as thank God that death is not an- niliation, but a transition from one sphere to another and in this tran sition we leave behind an influence that lives on to effect the lives of others. Our departed frieiyl and fellow councilman was gifted with the faculty of making and holding frends, a man just in the prime of life who had been in business here since graduating from school to the day of his death, admired and res pected by all who knew him not op vly as one of our best business men but as a man who could be trusted and relied upon. Clause and effect are inseparable. What was the cause of this confiedence and respect? Tad word was his bond, he held honor and integrity as a guiding star. Not a flatterer, but a plain spoken man standing four square for what he conceived to be right and just. We assure the bereaved family that we share with them the sorrow that must come to all at the loss of such -a loved one and frined. S .W . Sears had been a member of the council since September 1928, and his gn ial face -and fine business .advice will be missed by the body of whilch he was a member so long. F C. Dresser, H. G. Johnson, j  W. Cawthorn, Committee.

document.text: Lynchburg were dinner guests of Mrs. Jennie Johnson Sunday night. Mrs. S. J. Evans and daughter Ann will spend the week end with Mrs. Jennie Johnson. Rev. and Mrs. R. Carl Maxwell, Mrs. Rachael Lawson, and Mr. Ric hard D. Robinson attended a lun cheon meeting of Red Cross coordi nating committees at the Roanoke Hotel in Roanoke, Thursday, January 10. The next bloodmobile visit to Ap pomattox will be made April 19. Lieutenant Governor and Mrs. L. P. Collins of Marion were the week end guests of Congressman and Mrs. Watkins M. Abbitt. Mr. and Mrs. Channing Simpkins of Mount Hope, West Virginia, spent the Week end with Mrs. Simpkins father, J. W. Cawthorn. The Simp kins were en route to Florida for a vacation. R. L. Burke continues ill at his home here. The Burke relatives here during the week end included Mr. and Mrs. R. F. B. Steele and two daughters of Petersburg, Mr. Hallie Burke of Floyd, Mr. and Mrs. R. F. Burke of I ynchburg, and Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Williams of Brookneal. Miss Mar jorie Woody returned to Washington, Wednesday, after spend ing the past two months here as sec retary to Congressman Watkins M. Abbitt. Mrs. Lewis Winters who has Been a patient at the Lynchburg General Hospital, was carried to the Univer sity Hospital Wednesday, for further treatment. Mrs. W. B. Ellett of Roanoke is spending some time withe her sister, Mrs. Richard L. Burke. Billy Conner wil leave Friday for vacation in Florida. While away he will visit Harry G. Lawson, USN, Jacksonville. His mother, Mrs. Verna Conner, will accompany him as far as Rocky Mount, where she will visit elatives. Herbert C. Pulliam is spending sev eral days in Richmond, attending the opening sessions of the Virginia egislature. Mrs. Frank C. Dresser is in Lynch burg with her great nephew, William Herndon, Jr., who underwent an ope- ation at the Virginia Baptist Hos pital today. Mrs. Floyd Mitchell has returned home from Virginia Baptist Hospital where she underwent an operation Monday.

document.text: Heres a letter from Pvt. Warren Barlow to his mother, Mrs. K. V. Barlow, Appomattox, Va. Derr Mother, I received your letter today. Was lad to hear from you. I will fcr.ve o answer today. This will be the ist ime j can write you from here. T t . _ , .. ,   cant tell you where we are go- Up_to now we have three black- or whe we are goIng. l wU1 We outs effective in Appomattox. The first two were very successful. The last one was not thoroughly carried out. We believe the main reason for this was lack of understanding of what was expected. It was a combi nation dim-out and- blackout. We know, of course, that there were no intentional violations of the rules governing these tests. In either a dim-out or a black out, no lights should be seen from the streets. In a blackout, all people must be in their homes, or at least off the streets except those assist ing in the blackout. The only differ ence between a.dim-out and a black out, is that people may be on the streets during a dim-out, and traffic may continue as usual, with hooded lights. However, during a blackout, all citizens are supposed to be off the strets and all traffic slopped. In the event that you attempt, to us blackout shades br curtains, be sure to test them out a night or two b. forehand, to be certain that no light shines through or by your shades. Ordinary window shades do not blackout. No light, regardless of its color, should be visiblefrom the outside. Flashlights, lighted cigars or cigarettes or matches are prohibit ed. Civilian defense officers on duty during the blackout must guard against striking matches or smoking. In he past, the auxiliary police have called the peoples attention to any violation of the.rules, explaining the violation to them and asking.that it not be repeated. In the future, the o.ice will give no further warnings r.nd no explanations to any of us. It is felt by the State authorities that all of us have had sufficient expla nation and instructions regarding the regulations, and we should govern ourselves accordingly. We are in structed to say further that if any one is found in violation of any of the regulations governing dim-outs or black-outs, that person will auto matically and promptly be summons ed to the mayors court of the town of Appomattox. By order of the local defense council, Appomattox County Va - C. S. McDeaymon, mayor, Appomat tox, Va. George F. Abbitt Jr., di rector of Defense, Appomattox Co., Va. J. W. Cawthorn, town sergeant Appomattox, Va. D.A Comer, head of  Auxiliary Police,  Appomattox, Va. J. A. Burke, local Coordinator,

document.text: D It. CANNONS L E T T E R . Oct. 22, 1915. Mr. L. W. Hoffman, Pamplin, Va. Dear Mr. Hoffman As you know the victory for Statewide Prohibition wis won ony after i protracted struggle in the Legislature of Virginia, ex tending over several years and then after a strenuous bat tle, culminating on September 22. 1914. In order to reap the results of such a great expenditure of time, labor and money, it is exceedingly important that every diy  x50unty shall send as its Representative to the House ot Delegates a man whose devotion to the prohibi tion cause is undoubted, for tbe legislation to be passec will be much more influentia if it is passed by practically unanimous vote. It has been the policy of the Anti Saloon League from the begiuoiug of its works to fur hish to tbe citizens of the county where there is a contest, for public office the r?cords of tt e candidates so far as we can do so It is our understanding that there are two candidates for the Legislature from Appo mattox County namely, Mr. J W. Cawthorn and Mr. R. L Burke. The record of Mr. Cawthorn in the General Assembly o 1914 was not at all atisfactory The crucial vote iu the figh for the Enabling Act was the vote on the beport of the Con ference Committee. Had the adoption of that Report been defeated in the House of Dele gates, we could not have voted on Statewide Prohibition on September 22, 1914, and we would still be fighting for Legislature to give us an op portuoity to exercise our right to vote. Tho Journal of the House of Delegates shows that on that vote Mr. J. W Caw thorn of Appomattox is re corded as voting against the adoption of the Report. So that in view of his record at that critical time, the Anti Saloon League of Virginia con siders Mr. Cawthorn to be a mm who cannot be depended upon to be of any service in the passage of the prohibitory law by the General Assembly of 1916.

document.text: By order of the Electorial Board of Appomattox County, all Regis tration Books in Southside District shall be purged as of October 4 1954. The names listed below have been removed from the Registration Books, Courthouse Precinct, South- side District, Appomattox County Virginia for reasons of death transferred or moved. This action is provided for and ordered under Sec tions 24-94 through 24-107 of the Virginia Election Laws as amend ed. Any one who can prove conclus ively that any of the names listed below have a right to be on the Registration Books of said County of said district, they shall make such information available to the undersigned registrar. Harvey in his space, on 1st page Miss Alice Gawthorn, a train ed nurse of Catawba, is spend ing her vacation with her parents, Mr. and Mrs. J. W. Cawthorn, here. Mieses Gladys Patteson and Iliene Smith left Thursday night last for a ten-day vaca tion at Virginia Beach and Norfolk Mr. James H. Stanley, jr., after a few weeks spent at home since being mustered out of the army, has gone to Rich mond io work. Misses Mabel Conner and Wave Turnes, of Turnes Mill, are visiting their cousin, Miss Sadie Turnes, in Charlotte county this week. Mr. and Mrs. B. L. Jordan and family, of Charlotte county, spent Sunday at the house of Mr. and Mrs. H. C. Turnes at Hollywood. Miss Sadie Turne and friend, Mr. John Crute, of Charlotte county, were Sunday guests of Miss Edna Turnes at Turnes Mill. Grand Patron S. H. Huddles ton, of Roanoke, will be here Saturday, July 19th, at 7 p. m., to install a Chapter at Appo mattox of the Eastern Star. The place of meeting will be at Masonic Hall.

document.text: Appomattox may ye.t share in the public and civil works projectsbeing encouraged by the federal administration. A large group, including Don Moses, J. W. Cawthorn. C. W. Smith, F- A. OBrien, J H. OBrien, T. E. Owen, S. L. Ferguson, E. T. Mitchl and Watt Abbitt attended a called meeting of town and, county of ficials of this section in Faripr ville yesterday afternoon. Pos sible work projects in the ter ritory were urged. The civil works administra tion is ready to grant funds to carry out a great number of relatively small projects in or der to.restore employment. It is hoped that 2,000,000 men can be put to work vithin a few weeks time, therefore smaller projects that can be undertaken on short notice, 1 giving immediate employment,  are being pushed. The group from Appomat-  tox considered application for funds to properly drain sew age disposal within the town of Appomattox, possible street and sidewalk wotk, sewage, painting of interior and exter iors of county schools, small ad dirions to schools, possible heating plant In larger schobls- It appears that the original plan to install a town owned water and sewage plant here will not be carried through. However, the time is auspicious for public works here and tho federal government knbckrf at the door of opportunity offer ing funds to finance any reas onable projects. With towns, cities and coun ties being granted large sums for public projects and giving subsequent employment a n d aid to the financial welfare of the people, it is felt that Appo mattox should not be left out. Public opinioji and pressure will make it possible for not one family honestly desiring to work to go unemployed this winter in Appomattox. How ever, speed must be the decid ing factor in lining up the de sired applications- ---------  ---- o -------- - -------

Born in Prince Edward County, she was a daughter of the late J. W. Cawthorn tad Lizzie Morris Cawthorn. She was a member of Mémorial United Methodist Church. She is surviyed by a . daughter, Mrs. Edith S. By set of Vienna three sisters, Mrs. Thelma Caldwell, Mrs. Nell Thrasher, and Mrs. Clara . Hanenkrat, all of Appomattox two granddaughters and two great-granddaughten. Funeral services were con ducted Monday, August 24 at Robinson Funeral Home at 2 p.m. with burial Wednesday at 10 a.m. in Oak Hill, West Virginia.
